summary: This is a compilation of news clips from August 14, 2019, primarily covering the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It includes victim accounts, political reactions, investigations into jail security failures, and updates on other SDNY cases. The document highlights the public and legal fallout from Epstein's apparent suicide, calls for accountability, and ongoing legal proceedings.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Financier accused of sex trafficking minors who was found dead in his jail cell. Multiple articles discuss his crimes, death, and the legal aftermath.

persons.name: Jennifer Araoz
persons.context: A woman who publicly accused Epstein of raping her when she was 15 and filed a civil action under the Child Victims Act.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Republican senator from Nebraska who sent letters to Attorney General Barr demanding the 2008 Epstein plea deal be ripped up and answers about his death in custody.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Attorney General who promised accountability for Epstein's death and to pursue co-conspirators. Ordered investigations into the jail suicide.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: British socialite and Epstein's former girlfriend, accused of procuring underage victims for him. Articles discuss her whereabouts and alleged role.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who negotiated the 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein. Lost his cabinet position over the deal.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: Warden of the Metropolitan Correctional Center who was temporarily reassigned pending investigation into Epstein's death.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.context: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who vowed to continue the investigation into Epstein and his co-conspirators.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's younger brother, discussed in relation to business ties and real estate connections, including offering his home for bond.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.context: Tech CEO reported to be in a relationship with Ghislaine Maxwell and living with her in a Massachusetts mansion.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Epstein's MC2 modeling agency business partner, accused by a victim of sexual misconduct.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Florida attorney representing several of Epstein's alleged victims, quoted about Epstein housing models in his brother's building.

persons.name: Ben Sprecher
persons.context: Broadway producer arrested on federal child pornography charges, unrelated to Epstein but covered in the news clips.

persons.name: Greg Craig
persons.context: Former Obama White House lawyer whose trial for lying to investigators about Ukrainian work was postponed.

persons.name: Steven Donziger
persons.context: Suspended attorney facing criminal contempt prosecution related to the Chevron Ecuador lawsuit.

persons.name: Rita Glavin
persons.context: Attorney at Seward & Kissel appointed as special prosecutor to pursue criminal contempt charges against Steven Donziger.

persons.name: Joel Margulies
persons.context: Marketing professional convicted of fraud for helping steal millions from snack and pet food investors.

persons.name: Sohrab Sharma
persons.context: Co-founder of Centra Tech, facing fraud charges related to a cryptocurrency initial coin offering.

persons.name: Robert Farkas
persons.context: Co-founder of Centra Tech, facing fraud charges related to a cryptocurrency initial coin offering.

persons.name: Faheem Walter
persons.context: Former bodyguard for rapper Tekashi69, sentenced for his role in a restaurant shooting.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's former girlfriend, closest pal, and alleged sex procurer/madam who helped recruit victims.
Araoz accuses Epstein of raping her when she was 15 after being recruited by one of his recruiters.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, negotiated the controversial 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges.
Mark is Jeffrey Epstein's younger brother. Documents show business ties between Mark's real estate company and Jeffrey's company.
Reported to be in a relationship and living together in a secluded Massachusetts mansion.
Brunel was Epstein's business partner in the MC2 modeling agency and is accused by a victim of sexual misconduct.
Senator Sasse sent letters to Attorney General Barr demanding action on the Epstein case and investigation into his death.
Glavin was appointed as a special prosecutor to pursue criminal contempt charges against Donziger.

events.title: Araoz's first visit to Epstein's mansion
events.description: Jennifer Araoz, then 14, first visited Jeffrey Epstein's Upper East Side mansion in the fall of 2001, marking the beginning of her alleged abuse.

events.title: Epstein's non-prosecution agreement
events.description: U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta negotiated a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, granting him and potential co-conspirators immunity from federal charges in exchange for a state guilty plea.

events.title: Epstein arrested on sex trafficking charges
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on federal sex trafficking charges in New York.

events.title: Epstein's first suicide attempt in custody
events.description: Epstein was found injured in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, resulting in him being placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein found dead in jail cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 6:30 a.m., an apparent suicide by hanging.

events.title: Guards placed on leave for falsifying logs
events.description: Two correctional officers guarding Epstein's unit were placed on administrative leave for allegedly falling asleep and falsifying log entries about checking on him.

events.title: Araoz files civil action
events.description: Jennifer Araoz filed a civil action against Jeffrey Epstein's estate and accomplices under New York's Child Victims Act.

events.title: Ben Sprecher arrested on child porn charges
events.description: Broadway producer Ben Sprecher was arrested on federal charges of possession and distribution of child pornography.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, Manhattan, New York
Epstein's mansion, Upper East Side, Manhattan, New York
Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts (where Ghislaine Maxwell was reportedly living)
301 East 66th Street, Manhattan (building owned by Mark Epstein where Jeffrey Epstein allegedly housed associates)
Palm Beach, Florida (location of another Epstein mansion)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his jail cell on August 10, 2019, in an apparent suicide by hanging.
Two correctional officers guarding Epstein's unit were placed on leave for allegedly falsifying logs and failing to check on him for about three hours.
Victim Jennifer Araoz publicly accused Epstein of raping her when she was 15 and filed a civil lawsuit under the Child Victims Act on August 14, 2019.
Senator Ben Sasse urged Attorney General Barr to 'rip up' the 2008 non-prosecution agreement to pursue Epstein's co-conspirators.
Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein's alleged accomplice, was reported to be living in seclusion with tech CEO Scott Borgerson in a Massachusetts mansion.
